description: Health begins where we live, work and play. Students are immersed in public, private, and
community-based organizations in Northfield (rural) and Minneapolis-St. Paul (urban) to
gain an understanding of the social determinants of health (environmental conditions,
resources and supports) and the relationship to individual health outcomes through service
learning. A special emphasis is placed on the impact of socioeconomic status, geographic
location, and disability on health disparities.  Offered occasionally during Interim. Apply
through International and Off-Campus Studies.  Prerequisite: one course in sociology/anthropology,
women's and gender studies, social work, family studies, economics, political science,
fullname: Health and Social Inequality: Rural/Urban Perspectives (off campus)
